If you're looking for a free-roaming game like Grand Theft Auto, fuhgeddaboutit. Mafia 2 has an open world, stores to shop at or rob, a police system, and many other things you'd expect from that sort of game, but like Mafia 1, the game is a lot more structured, and instead of having much in terms of side content it plays out like a traditional game campaign, with little time for free roaming. But the game's world is still well-designed, even if it's mostly pretty window dressing, and it makes the campaign feel more alive than it would if it was just a corridor shooter. It's not an amazing game, but it is a unique one. Mafia 2 is the kind of game where the police are actually police, and even though they'll probably never catch you they'll still try to ticket you for breaking the speed limit. It's the kind of game that isn't afraid to be a little tedious to give a sense of contrast between a 'normal life' and the mafia life, like an early level that has you packing crates into the back of a truck to test your patience until you give up and leave. The developers do a good job at recreating the time period, and the cars, radio, and weapons all handle and sound pretty nice. The story and gunplay are both pretty well-done, and overall if you're a fan of mafia stories like The Godfather than Mafia 2 is worth a shot, as long as you don't go in expecting a true open world game.

Mafia II. Note that I have, at this moment in time, never before played Mafia I.   Although I have played other such titles, for example Mafia Wars, The Godfather games, Omerta City of Gangsters and of course GTA and also Saints Row.   This game, has by far one of the most gripping main story lines I have come across for this genre. (Personally)   I played this first on Xbox 360, and I have many many hours clocked.    Now I shall tell you about a few features.    Car mechanics;  the driving is lovely and realistic. No manual gear changing or first person head turning ( I belive there is a fine working modification for first person) but everything works smoothly as it should. You can turn on or off a speedomiter on as far as I know all cars. There is also an option to turn on or off realistic driving ( more slipping when it's wet with rain and snow, realistic breaking, that sort of thing. ) Car damage is very well done and there is a car mechanic shop at your service, as well as a few other types of shops : ) you as the player cannot shoot out of windows as far as I know without some sort of modification to the game, but other NPCs in the car can and will if need be ( if they use a gun normally xD ) You can open the bonnet and boot of most cars, which is a lovely feature :) they really did well on the cars, I mean you can take the hubcaps off from damage.. taking out the lights and tyres is very fun and rewarding.. shooting through the windows is very nice.. the bumpers bounce about nicely when they partly come apart.. spinning out and drifting is very nice, aaandd, you can shoot the sirens to stop them xD! There are many many vechicles to see and drive, from armoured vans and trucks to small sports cars and hotrods : D.   Next is the violence mechanics;   Shooting is very well done, you can also punch up enemies with your fists.. the fighting is well done!   You can kill someone instantly if you shoot the head, so there is minor locational damage, and all animations are very good. There is blood also.  There is a good cover system, alowing you to take cover on most objects however they are. You can also destroy most objects as you please.  Atmosphere;  It feels veryy genuine. The music, crisp textures and wonderful lighting provides a truly nineteen thirtys to seventys feel. Something perhaps out of The Italian Job, or a James Bond movie..   There are many many songs out on the few radio stations.. from home radio to car radio you can listen all the time :D  Oh, voice acting is absolutly top notch. For the most part there are no hiccups!  You can dress differently, answer phones and use rest rooms, buy drinks and food, and take a stroll out and about.   I love this game. I hope you will or do too :)

Mafia II is a game that should be played mainly for its Story. The pace is great from the very beginning were it tells the Story of your character when you were younger and how you end up doing what you are doing. You start doing little jobs here and there to get some money to pay a debt left by a family member. Right from the start you feel that family is the most important thing but as you go deeper and deeper you realize that it's hard to not involve the ones you care because of your decisions. As you go through the Story you experience a better life with better cars, a better house and most of all, more money, however, the main character wonders if this is what he really wanted to have when you end up doing things you may not feel proud of.   When you start the game it's Winter time. It's cold and it snows a lot. The roads are slippery and covered in snow. After some certain events I won't spoil, you return to the city during Spring time where everything feels more alive. More bright colors, people driving their convertible cars and the streets are finally filled with green grass without any sign of snow. As always, it's great to drive around town when it starts to rain. Feels good. This was a good idea to give you the feeling that time is passing. It's always interesting to see a different season after some time when playing a game.   The visuals are really well done. Facial animations are really good and they made a great job with the details on the characters faces such little scars or others 'imperfections'. The city feels amazing and things like bridges have great textures and look particulary well done. You can see that there was a big effort on the little details around the city too. Posters, prints and the Marketing about Cars, beer and other products are really well done using the culture from the time like the pin-up style.   There are not many side quests or activities to do as someone might expect from other open games but the Story makes up for it leaving you interested from start to finish. There are however some Collectibles that may extend your play through such the Playboy Magazines which is a nice touch and I'm sure it will take many more effort from players to search for them since they can be more interesting than, say, collecting dog tags or audio logs for completion purposes.  Bottom line, this was a good game with an interesting Story. I had great fun with it but I think it's time to move to the next game on my Backlog. I would honestly recommend this game and if you like the setting then you won't be disappointed to see the work they put in recreating these times paid of. *  Side curiosities:  - Some people requested this game to be banned in Italy due the fact that it could damage the portrait of Italian-Americans.  - It's one of the games that uses the 'F' word the most (more than 200 times).  - While there are Playboy magazines to be collected these did not exist in the time the game was occurring (1945 to 1951) only 7 years later in 1953. As for the images from the game itself they are from 1958 to 1968.

Born the son of a poor immigrant, Vito is a beaten down Italian American who is trying to secure his piece of the American Dream. Looking to escape the life of poverty that consumed his childhood, Vito is soon swayed by the lure of power and wealth that a life of Organized Crime can bring.  A petty criminal his whole life, Vito, along with his childhood friend, Joe, will descend into the world of Organized Crime. Together, they will work to prove themselves to the Mob as they try to make their names on the streets of a cold and unforgiving city.  Mafia 2 immerses players in the mob underworld of a fictitious late 1940's / early 1950's scenario. The game engages you in a cinematic Hollywood movie experience in a living, breathing city, fusing high octane gunplay with white knuckle driving and an engaging narrative .

Ok, so where to start.... well done.  I say this with a caveat... that the game allows for replayability quite well in fact, but that it does not beckon such beyond control. It does not petition me to return, almost begging, but I know if I did, it would be enjoyable.  The role played is very well developed. It leaves plenty of time through the story line for the whole picture to be displayed, and although there is no leveling up or character development in the abilities gained or power increased sense, still gives much body to the perception that you are becoming more. The graphics are well designed, although slightly out of date, and are well rounded. Playability is not hindered by flavor and 'flowery touch ups' which add to the depth of the story, and I found no bugs during my playthrough on hard difficulty.  It is challenging at times, others a bit simpler and not as demanding. It does not get old or tired as to doing the same thing over and over... which is always a big thing for me as I revel in chaos and variety, and even the other characters speech and conversations do not break the atmosphere.  Overall, I would say this game is very enjoyable, leaves room and availability for replay, has challenge to it, and respects the age and experiences of mature people, also something I find lacking in most games.  In terms of mechanics, the only downside I found over all, and keep in mind this is after my having already enjoyed Fallout 4, Witcher 3, and Skyrim, is that (SPOILER ALERT) at various times in the game, you lose all your money, and most of the flavor add-ons such as suits etc. As mentioned already, the role is played almost flawlessly, and this aspect is no exception. Fortunately, by most standards and once you've played through a sufficient amount of the game, losing your money does not prevent you from continuing through the story, nor does it somehow make you less of a badass if your skills improve as they should with time. That being said, the concept that I can 'go home' at any time and the goodies that i've acquired will still be there, was lost; but take it with a grain of salt... the items lost can be acquired again without much time or difficulty, and you never lose your cars. :)   I would highly recommend this game. I believe most anyone even with quite vast differences in playstyles and genre preferences would find enjoyment with this game.  Good hunting.

I've been on an open-world game kick recently, and figured I would check out Mafia II before the sequel came out to see what all the fuss is about. Mafia II has moments of greatness and and some weird design quirks.  The biggest quirk seems to be that it's not really an open world game as there is no sense of exploration, no real gameplay systems that exist on their own, and time only passes to serve the main plot line. You get the idea that either it might have been a true open world game given an extra year to develop it, or that 2K games at that time just wanted everything to be open world no matter what so all that work was shoved in there for no reason. The majority of linear mission set pieces aren't even part of the open world locations, taking place on rooftops or warehouses or different locations entirely.  Which is confusing because what little exists of the open world is fantastic and had a lot of work put into it. The technology is really quite good for 2010. The seamless roads, distant LODs and number of pedestrians is up there with anything. The winter in the 40's feels exactly like how the movies show NYC. Snow and grime builds on your cars and everything inside has a cozy vibe. The dimmed sense of color and snow everywhere gives an almost black and white vibe, with Dean Martin's let it snow playing on the radio (despite not being period accurate... in general the game is not). The soundtrack is enormous (137 tracks from the era, vs fallout 4's 37). It is cool to walk around in an three piece suit and overcoat and also be in a crowd of other people wearing the same thing. Simiarly the cars are old-fashioned 80 hp steel death traps and drive and sound appropriately. Later on when things become a bit more vibrant sticking to your 3 piece suit and hat gives it a mad men feeling.  I found the writing quite solid, but is ultimately limited by the linear nature of the gameplay as well as the game developer mindset of this time where people tried to turn games into movies. All of the interesting stuff happens in cutscenes and you just ferry between them. I am glad they didn't try to whitewash history when it came to racism and such, but they also fell into quite a few tropes of their own which are areas for improvement.  It is worth picking up for cheap. Even if all you do is play the first couple hours it is worth it to check out the city a bit.

So before I get into this, it should be noted that Mafia II is no longer available on the Steam Store as I write this, if you already own the game you can install and play it, but if you don't, you're going to have to wait for a bit, it should be noted that Mafia II just turned 5 the day of its takedown, because the game uses licensed music tracks in the in-game radio stations, it's possible that the digital takedown is a direct result of this.  Buttttt to the review of the game, starting with the backstory:  Mafia II is a Third-Person shooter where the player takes control of Vito Scalleta, an Italian-American who immigrated to Empire Bay, United States from Sicily, Kingdom of Italy in 1931, Vito being born in 1925, Vito's family is thrown into debt and economic difficulty, the great depression hitting them hard, eventually Vito and childhood friend Joe Barbaro form a close relationship in their teenage years, Vito's father drowns in the docks he works at so Joe and Vito have to turn to a life of crime to make ends meet.  After Vito is arrested for attempted robbery in 1943, he is given two choices: Jail, or fight for the US army in Operation Husky, the allied invasion of Sicily, Vito being fluent in Italian and Sicilian as well as English. It is here when the player takes control of Vito, as he and his band of US marines help liberate a smal Sicilian town, San Celeste, from Fascist Blackshirts loyal to Benito Mussolini, Vito is eventually injured later during the war and is temporarily discharged after being healed up, but is due to return to the front in a few months, after meeting up with his family, and finding out his younger sister still has to pay back debts of their father, Vito also meets up with Joe, who finds a way to get Vito fake papers to get him out of service. Vito, wanting to pay back his father's debt, decides that honest labor won't cut it, so he turns to the Mafia families in Empire Bay to get him enough cash to pay his late father's debt.  The game is great, a great plot with great characters, voice actors, music selection, and dialogue, Mafia 2, even if it can be beaten quickly, provides for hours of content and excellent gameplay, however, there are some things you should know about it:  This game, while being an open world game, doesn't have a 'free roam' mode (however there are mods that add this), and the game doesn't function like GTAV or Red Dead Redemption, where the game is in Free Roam all the time an you travel to missions in the world, this game functions more like L.A. Noire (another excellent title) where missions are the only way to access the world, as there isn't a free-roam mode. The game is still excellent regardless of the free-roam, and it's able to provide an excellent story with plot twists, betrayals, and surprise plot developments, Mafia 2 is an excellent purchase and once it is available on the Steam Store again, if you haven't gotten if already, you certainly should. It is here when the player takes control of Vito, as he and his band of US marines help liberate a smal Sicilian town, San Celeste, from Fascist Blackshirts loyal to Benito Mussolini, Vito is eventually injured later during the war and is temporarily discharged after being healed up, but is due to return to the front in a few months, after meeting up with his family, and finding out his younger sister still has to pay back debts of their father, Vito also meets up with Joe, who finds a way to get Vito fake papers to get him out of service. Vito, wanting to pay back his father's debt, decides that honest labor won't cut it, so he turns to the Mafia families in Empire Bay to get him enough cash to pay his late father's debt.  The game is great, a great plot with great characters, voice actors, music selection, and dialogue, Mafia 2, even if it can be beaten quickly, provides for hours of content and excellent gameplay, however, there are some things you should know about it:  This game, while being an open world game, doesn't have a 'free roam' mode (however there are mods that add this), and the game doesn't function like GTAV or Red Dead Redemption, where the game is in Free Roam all the time an you travel to missions in the world, this game functions more like L.A. Noire (another excellent title) where missions are the only way to access the world, as there isn't a free-roam mode. The game is still excellent regardless of the free-roam, and it's able to provide an excellent story with plot twists, betrayals, and surprise plot developments, Mafia 2 is an excellent purchase and once it is available on the Steam Store again, if you haven't gotten if already, you certainly should. I'm sure many people will request someone judge this game based on Grand Theft Auto or a similar game. However that's a mistake. Mafia 2 is NOT a GTA game, while yes there's a world, and you can explore the game as you want at times, this is an extremely linear story, with only one part of the game (A scant ten minutes) which gives you an open ended task. That's 10 minutes of an almost 15 hour game.   A quick note: I was not a fan of the original Mafia. However I was curious about the desire for Mafia 3 so I tried this game out.   That's not to say someone can't compare them, but the point is this is a VERY story driven game. If you're not a fan of Mafia movies, you're probably going to dislike this game. Not only is it heavily based on the same subject, but much of the game is similar to those movies. That's not to say they stole from the movies or anything, but as I played I noticed a number of scenes that feel lifted from Godfather. Hell you have a guy named Vito making his way up.   Then again this story isn't like even GTA Vice City, where the entire game is just a retelling of Scarface, instead there's a very solid and good story that involves a number of interesting characters, and honestly, while you might have an idea where the end of the game is (seriously, mafia stories end only two ways). The game delivers it's story well.  There's no open world component here, even at the end of the game, there's no true free roam. As I said there's 10 minutes of free roam when you need to make a little money. But the majority of the game allows you to explore the city and see everything but there's nothing to do besides the next mission. It's a lovely vibrant city and it's not a huge fault, but if someone's looking for a ton of stuff to do, this isn't the game. If someone instead wants a solid narrative and a story that drives the player forward, well Mafia 2 does that.   I kept playing because I wanted to see the end of the game, and when I was done, I thought I enjoyed it. I'd give this game a 4 stars. That other star. Well let's get into some negatives.   First off I found one almost game breaking bug, in chapter 12, apparently entering a building through one door instead of the other broke the script and that's a pretty major bug, I was ready to give up through frustration before someone mentioned a fix in a thread I read. A fix from 4 years ago! Come on 2k!.   Second we need to talk about collectibles. Let's first talk about the bad. There's wanted posters, and a few of them are near impossible to collect. And there's 159 of them!! Come on! Not only is there too many, but collectibles shouldn't be impossible to get.   On the other hand, there's another collectible. As you play through the story, there's chapters and each chapter has 2-4 playboys. Yes Playboys, you collect the magazine and get a pin up picture. And um, yeah they're old classic pin up photos. To put it simply, it's odd. I mean in a game that has no nudity, even when a character showers, or when there's numerous girls around, there's just porn in the collectibles. WTF? I'm not complaining mind you, it's just a very odd choice. Though making it so you have to collect them as you play through the story was a good design choice in my opinion, it meant you would go near them (For the most part) and have to collect them then, as if you try to grab one in an area you can get to in the wrong chapter, it wouldn't be there.   The gameplay is solid, I've heard people rag about the gunplay, but it's quite good. The difficulty of the game is pretty easy, up til the final chapters, where hard gets ridiculously hard, but medium is almost never a challenge. There's even an option to turn on simulation driving, that did make the car control more realistically. A great addition but I turned it off after a while. It really is nice, but why add difficulty in evading police?   And finally let's talk about the music. I love it, this game has everything, old Italian standards, doo wop, and as the story is told over two decades the music changes with the time. It's a brilliant use of music to push the story forward.   Now I got this game in a humble bundle, I should mention that, but this game made me excited about Mafia 3. When Mafia 3 comes out, I'll be watching because if it can deliver a game, and a story like this one. I won't really have a problem paying for it. As I mentioned earlier, I didn't like Mafia 1 that much, Mafia 2 is a complete 180, I really enjoyed this game. I wouldn't call it love, and I wish people were more upfront about it not being a sandbox/open world game, but besides that, it's a fantastic game, and was well worth the 15 or so hours I put into the main story.   Strong recommend.

For most though that's probably perfectly fine, I still have a full stomach of this type of fiction from my teenage years - that's partially where 'Consigliere' comes from - and as such, a lot of the story elements felt cheap, in lack of a better term. It was also very, very predictable, there's a lot of Scorsese storytelling going on which is great but I feel like I've seen this movie a hundred times. It even basically ends the same way as all gangster fiction does, 'I got into this life to get rich and powerful but in the end it cost me more than it was worth' type situation, which is probably faithful to reality but again, I've seen it a hundred times. At least it wasn't a dopey revenge tale like so many of these games tend to be.  I do think the Mafia games possibly have the most intelligent wanted level system I've ever seen for an open-world crime game, its basically the same system from the first game's where the car you're driving can be wanted, but if the police don't have your description (ie haven't seen you outside of the vehicle), you can switch cars and the wanted level is instantly gone no matter how high it is. If they HAVE seen you, all it takes is a change of clothes, or for situations where that isn't plausible, you have a couple of ways to bribe your way out, but its expensive. Or, there is a chance where a cop sees you commit a crime but isn't able to get your description OR your plate number, in which case all you have to do is outrun him for a short period of time. All in all I like how that works, it makes logical sense and practical sense, not just one or the other like in, say, Grand Theft Auto. The Police AI is a crapload better than the first game too, cops will actually stop crimes committed by NPCs now (or attempt to). It was really kinda bad in the first game, as I remember it.   ts still not perfect, I can get fined for speeding or crashing into cars, but I can drive on the sidewalk and run redlights and cops don't give a flying ♥♥♥♥; if you're going to implement traffic laws then go all the way, or just leave it out (which would've been my preference). You also can run out of gas, and there are gas stations to refill at, but I never once ran out of fuel except when trying to do a specific achievement and even if I had I would've just stolen another ride, so that's another mechanic I could do without. I remember there being a licensed Godfather game for the PS2, I feel like this game could've copied some of the gameplay tropes from it, such as territory wars, or extorting individual businesses, etc would've benefitted it greatly, but it also admittedly would've distracted from the 'cinematic experience', which is something this series is all about having (moreso the first game though). Also despite the presence of public transportation, there's no means of fast travel, that disappointed me.  I got this as a part of the Humble Bundle, the 2K bundle that several of us partook in (and honestly had no expectation that I'd ever pick this up before that sale, I liked the first game in its time but that time was long ago); having paid around $8 for all those games, I think this is a good (not great) experience. If I'd paid $60 or even $30, however, I think I'd be a lot more critical; perhaps that's the best review I could give, in that sentence.

After the disappointment that was Mafia III I decided to replay Mafia II 6 years on from the first time I played it and I had forgotten just how polished it was for the time, and even now it holds up incredibly well.   The story is great and is pushed along nicely by some incredible voice work and a very capable script. You become attached to the characters on screen and the main cast all have their own personalities and quirks which helps make them feel more real.   Gameplay wise it's solid but simple, there's a basic cover system and a fighting mechanic which lets you punch the *bleep* out of your foes, sadly there are no melee weapons though which would have been great. The enemy AI for the most part are very smart and will often cover each other and try to flank you, sometimes they're even a little too quick off the draw as they come flying around a corner and instantly blow your head clean off, this is an area where Mafia II greatly surpasses the much newer Mafia III where enemies seem more than happy to stand around while you butcher their friends. You'll spend a lot of time driving your car and you have the option to play with simulation or arcade controls, personally I preferred arcade. Regardless as to which you pick cars handle well and the driving portion of the game feels more than fine.   Another huge plus is the audio which is just fantastic, I've already commented on the voice work which is superb but the game also has a massive library of music from the era which really makes long car rides more enjoyable as you tap your foot along to the tunes.   Visually it's still very nice 6 years later, it completely holds up and honestly looks better than some games that released much later, and you'll have no trouble hitting a solid 60fps on modern hardware as well so gameplay feels smooth and responsive at all times.   There are a couple of niggles though, one being the lack of unique character models for lesser characters, when you get to a certain part of the game this becomes highly noticeable when everyone of the same race has the exact same model, it's very jarring, I wonder how long it would have taken to add some beards or something just to make them a little different. Another, more annoying issue is the extremely harsh checkpoint system, dying for any reason can mean some lengthy backtracking and it really did frustrate me at times, you can't manually save so you're at the mercy of the game and you're going to die even on medium difficulty so I'm sure most people will experience some frustrating due to this during their first playthrough.   Overall I highly enjoyed Mafia II (again) and I recommend it to anyone, especially when it's on sale which it regularly is for £4.99. The DLC is not worth it, though.

Mafia II is an action-adventure video game developed by 2K Czech and published by 2K Games. The game is the direct sequel to 2002's Mafia: The City of Lost Heaven. Set within the fictional Empire Bay (based on New York City, Chicago, Los Angeles, Boston and Detroit, the story follows a gangster and his efforts to climb through the ranks of the Mafia crime families. The game is played from a third-person perspective and its world is navigated on-foot or by vehicle. You take control Vito Scaletta, a war veteran who becomes caught up with the Mafia when trying to pay back his father's debts.   The game is set in the 1940s - early 1950s era of Empire Bay, a fictional city based on New York City, Chicago, Los Angeles, Boston and Detroit. There are 30-40 vehicles in the game (45 with downloadable content) as well as licensed music from the era. Many firearms from the previous game return, such as the Thompson submachine gun and Colt 1911, as well as a pump-action shotgun. New World War II-era weapons like the MP 40, the M3 submachine gun, the MG 42 and the Beretta Model 38 also appear in the game. Interacting with objects in the environment involves two action buttons- a standard action and a 'violent' action (for example, when stealing a car, the player may choose to either pick its lock or break the window glass), used in context-sensitive situations.   A map is included as in the original Mafia game, but the checkpoint system has been completely overhauled New controls include a cover system that allows you to take cover behind objects (such as generators, walls and large crates) and shoot enemies, rather than just entering an arbitrary crouch pose behind them. The game's cutscenes are created by the game engine in real-time. For example, if you're riding in a car and a cut scene starts, you will be driving the same car with the same condition (damaged or intact) and you will also be wearing the same clothes.   This game is just phenomenal both of the main characters are well fleshed-out and memorable, and the story just comes to an end in an original but shocking manner. Overall I think Mafia II really is a huge improvement over the first game. The chronic oversaturation of the mafia in our international media has taught us much. Mafia II is an attempt to chronicle these teachings in game form. Fact number one: mafia men do lots of killing. Fact number two: they like suits. Fact number three: mafiosa don't call each other mafiosa; they use the term 'wiseguys'.  I've cross-referenced facts one and two with Mafia II, and they're definitely right – a lot of killing and a lot of suits. Fact number three isn't. 'Wiseguys', with its implied streetsmarts and cunning, doesn't fit Mafia II's mobsters. It certainly doesn't fit the mid-level gangster the game asked me to tail early in its middle act, who didn't have the presence of mind to check his rearview mirror as he drove away from a literal hatchet job. Had that guy done so, he'd have seen Sicilian-born WWII veteran and new-boy mobster Vito Scaletta about 20 feet behind, dressed in a red and white cod- Hawaiian shirt, driving a hot pink corvette with 'BUMS12' proudly displayed on the numberplate. That guy was not very wise.  The other guy was me, and I was trying to be too wise. As Mafia II's protagonist, my first attempt to trail the escaping mobster ended in failure after my original car choice – an inconspicuous '50s saloon – was outpaced with ease on the motorways. I only chose that car, snatched unattended with a bit of pavement minigame lockpicking, to satisfy the mission briefing, which said my mark would notice anything too obvious. Dutifully I wrested against the vehicle's slightly clunky era-specific handling to try and keep pace. But after my AI target had pranged his own vehicle six times against anything and everything in his path, I realised that such forwardthinking wiseguyishness wasn't entirely necessary on my part.  That Mafia II so effectively harpoons its illusion of real life, showing its characters to be machines acting out prescribed paths, is to its detriment. But the fact that I bought into it in the first place is the game's greatest strength.  It's not that Vito is a sympathetic character. Returning from a war he held no moral stake in – after a botched robbery, it was that or prison – he joins the local mafia, even though his mum told him not to. Naughty. From there on, he relies upon menace through the typical mafioso triple-threat: punching, shooting, and scary staring. Best buddy Joe occasionally dips a toe into 'comic relief' territory, but then ducks back into 'just a bit nasty' land, gets his pistol and shoots everyone in comic relief territory. Those poor clowns.  The player's supporting cast eschews any chance to get really creative, instead furnishing the game with another layer of dark-suited, dark-haired professionals, hitmen and higher-ups that blur into one mass. Driven by his need for money and respect, Vito is encased in a series of ever-widening shells, each step up the mafia ladder (a ladder made of guns) giving a new set of faces to watch in cutscenes: but they're all congealed clichés, culled from a hundred Bronx Tales and Godfathers. The dialogue is wellwritten and excellently acted, but it feels mechanical, the spoutings of a supercomputer sat in a shady office with its dials set to 'lightly-accented macho threat.'  It was the city that drew me in. An amalgamation of New York's streets and Hollywood's hills, Empire Bay is as interactively sterile as all other 'open-world' game-cities, but it's been coated in a veneer of dreamy credibility. Each street and hallway has a feature – a man shouting at an open window; a woman pressing her ear to a door; the sound of an argument. It's easy to see these details written down in a design document, but it gives Empire Bay a genuine rhythm, a pulse that Liberty City lacks. Plus, it helps that it is – on hefty machines – stunning. Turn up in the city in winter, and the streets are caked in snow, with layered bands of crystalline white on the untrodden paths contrasting with slush on the roads. And the lights! Even as the game transitions out of the 1940s and into the '50s, Mafia II's waxy lighting remains consistently arresting, casting pools of gold and yellow on windscreens.  But there's no point to any of it. The city breathes and grows, changing as the missions span the years, but it never moves or cries out. The game is presented in chapters, and each chapter has you wake up in your home. Vito, I can inform you, is a man who sleeps in the same vest and pants for nine years. Before the poor, smelly bugger can even get dressed, he's hit with news and a job. The game forces you to drive to a location: once there, Vito either shoots some men, punches some men or drives to another location.  As their cheery local mafia man, I'd pop in to see my contacts. Need any guys whacking today? Anything nicked? Want me to punch a lady? I was good at all these things. But, always, no. To deviate from the missions just wastes time: you can rob shops, but won't procure much loot; you can pester civilians, but will only get police pressure. For a city dripping with incidental detail, the game slapped on top of it has none. Not that this is a mechanical problem – 2K Czech have never made any bones about Mafia II being a linear experience – but when the city itself looks so inviting, it's a shame you can't do more.  Unless you make your own fun, that is. I enjoyed people-watching in a city where every pedestrian and car driver has the situational awareness of a frightened rabbit. Drive near one of the AI humans on foot and their preset reactions kick in, launching them in a seemingly random direction. Sometimes, this would be toward safety; more regularly, they'd hurl themselves into speeding traffic.  Having a woman – a few moments earlier happily strolling down a sunny street – chuck herself in front of a nearby van is certainly a surprise. Having that van then swerve to try to avoid her and plough through another three pedestrians is brilliant. Having that van then be spotted by a police car, having those police open fire before getting squished by the panicky, blood-leaking van driver, is better than another cover-shooting 'kill 50 goons' story mission.  And those are too regular. Combat is supported by a pleasing system of gunplay that leads to weighty, inaccurate firefights heavily reliant on ducking behind cover. The enemy AI – so stupid at the wheel - doesn't redeem itself through Mafia II's battles. Bad guys just pop up and down from the same spots of cover like sharply dressed moles: whacking them is simply a matter of waiting. Early in the storyline, Mafia II displays a convincing unwillingness to murder indiscriminately, surmising that the repeated and wholesale murder of swathes of humanity isn't the mafia's major focus. This was the time I built my connections, prepared my lip for wobbling when my contacts became friends and my friends went to sleep with the fishes, as all mafia friends do. But then, three quarters of the way through, it forgets all that, and puts you up against waves of baddies, dehumanised after all that work to build Empire Bay's factions into tangible things.  Mafia II is a mafia movie run once through a game grinder, and that's simultaneously the worst thing about the game and the compliment it was developed for. In telling a story as convincing as most Hollywood depictions of the Cosa Nostra, 2K Czech have accomplished exactly what they intended to: only at the end does the artifice topple slightly, piling one too many game-cliché mass-battles onto the pile. But detach the story from its very familiar housings, and we're not left with much: a bit of walking, a lot of driving and too much shooting. Each is good, but rarely superb.  Even supported by a neat script and great voicework, Mafia II is treading ground already chewed up by cinema's very best. On that level, it can't compete. 80/100

It's been a while since I have played the first mafia game (which I very much enjoyed) so I'm not sure I remember it with great accuracy. Still, I'm going to give my opnion on mafia 2 based on this vague memory.  In short, it was a little disapointing... Now don't get me wrong, I still enjoyed my time with mafia 2 which took me around 18 hours to finish on hard difficulty (althugh 2 - 3 of those might be afk time) but it just felt so ... incomplete. From the moment you start the game you are being sent from one mission to the other without the game giving you a single story-justified break to roam around the city and see what is has to offer, yet upon getting a little deeper into the game you realize that this is probably due to the fact that other than the story, there is pretty much nothing to do. or at the very least nothing that would make you feel like it was worth doing.  In terms of story mafia 2 has a pretty good story and I enjoyed playing through it.  in terms of combat mafia 2 has some improvment over mafia 1. The shooting mechanics feels pretty much like mafia 1 only now you also have a cover mechanic. For hand to hand combat the developers made some boxing mode and while this addition is nice it is far from realizing it's potential. Oh, there are also no more meele weapons so that sucks.  In terms of cars the game feels pretty underwhelming with not as much vehichles as I remember mafia 1 having and cars seemingly not being a very significant part of the game, which is wierd since car customization is better than what mafia 1 had (if memory serves). Basically, the repair shops now let you change your car's color, tiers and lisence plates in addition to being able to fix it or even tune it's engine for better preformance. They also give you a private garage to store your cars in with room for up to 10 cars. In the garage you can browse the cars you have and view various statistics about each individual car as well as it's damage status. The problem with all of these 'cool' new things is that yet again they feel incomplete and instead of adding to the richness of the game they just remind you how much more & better it could have been.  Driving feels ok-ish but the camera can get frustrating. yet another incomplete feeling feature.  The story itself sometimes feels a little umm, ... ahem, wierd... in how it portrays killing and death as a 'big deal' in the cutscenes compared to the massive amout of it that you do while you play.  Free roaming, as you might have understood by now is boring, pointless and empty.   Despite all of the negatives above, mafia 2 is a nice gangster story driven game with fun shooting gameplay and some driving parts in between. If that is what you want than I recommend that you get the game once it's on sale.  Otherwise, If you were looking for some free roaming pleasure go get it elsewhere.

Highly recommended, but only for 50s fans.  Mafia II is a very barebones attempt at a GTA game. Don't get me wrong, the gameplay is fun and the story is great, but outside of the main campaign, there literally is not a single other mission in the game. The city is small, and contains only robable shops and illegitimate car salesmen in the way of economy or distractions. The freeride mode from Mafia 1 is even absent, though it's relatively easy to mod back in.  In no small words: After you beat the campaign, you're going to have to make your own fun in order to get your money's worth. This is where people are going to be split on the game.  Mafia II takes place in the 1940s and 50s (different sections of campaign, but the freeride mod lets you play both at your leisure). Currently, it is one of only two 1950s GTA shooters on the market, and one of only a small handful of 1940s GTA shooters. It's absolutely riddled with anachronisms in either setting, but the atmosphere is undeniable.  The root of this game is the unique experience of driving a T-Bird through a detailed, beautiful 1950s cityscape with oldies blasting out of your radio. It's an experience that I loved, and it's why I can say Mafia II gave me my money's worth. However, I can see how it's a bit too limited for some.  If you're not a fan of this kind of atmosphere, you should still buy it when it's on sale just to experience the great campaign. But if you're a huge 50s fan like me just looking for a game to suit your needs, this is the best you'll get.

AWESOME !! Reaaally aaawesome game !! Loved it from beginning to end, and will definitely play it again in a few months/years, I think it's just perfect !! It left me wanting more, but also left me with a feeling that I had exactly enough. Kind of like the feeling you get when you finish a really good meal, and you've had just enough that you do want more, that you'd come back another time. And you end up never coming back, and it becomes just a good memory. See ? I hope nobody will make other mafia games for a long time. I'll take that one expansion, but I'm not going to want anything more after that, simply because I know it would be just the same : double-crossing all the time, car chases and gun fights, immoral stuff and characters with italian accents, and I've had perfectly enough of it (in a good way). I wouldn't want to ruin this happy feeling. :)) This game did a perfect job, and I very highly doubt any other game will ever top this one, at least for a long time, in terms of action-oriented mafia games like this one here.  Now some people might argue that the map is not big enough, that the sandbox in this game is not that good. I do agree in a way; If you are someone that just likes to mess around in a sandbox, then I suppose that game is not for you, but if you want an excellent story, excellent pacing, excellent gameplay, perfectly reproduced mafia setting, etc etc, this one is for you. Personally, I felt the sandbox was there just enough so that it wouldn't draw you too far away from the story that you'd end up losing interest in the story. There could have been more sandbox elements, but it wasn't pushed onto the player, and it was good like that.  I do have one thing to say about the sandbox though. THIS REVIEW IS OF MAFIA 2 AS WELL AS THE DLC CONTENT: JIMMY'S VENDETTA AND JOE'S ADVENTURES  Mafia 2 is in my opinion an absolute masterpiece. This game caught me COMPLETELY off guard when it came out. I was not expecting it to be as good as it was. You play as Vito Scaletta who joins the Mob life thanks to the help of his friend in a 1940s city. You will be shooting, driving fighting and even getting involved in a few sneaking sections to get through the game. What keeps the game going is the story which constantly gives you context to keep playing through the game, similar to what TV shows do to keep them addictive. The game's story is absolutely stellar and always gives you a good enough reason to keep playing. There is also a very good hint of realism which I loved and also helped keep the game fun and addicting to get through.   The game also gives you plenty of opportunities to explore and go to shops to purchase guns and clothing to make your character look badass. The shooting is also solid and the game feels like one giant interactive movie. And I absolutely love it. I cannot reccomend this game enough. I LOVE IT. I'm not going to spoil the game, just know that the story is amazing and the mechanics, while not the best in the world, do work and work well with the game and it's story.  Can the same be said about Jimmy's Vendetta though? Unfortunately, no. This DLC was boring. Very boring. It actually highlights how good the story is, but also highlights that the game's mechanics on their own are actually not that brilliant. All the missions involve going to the mission point (which can sometimes be on the other side of the map), going to point A, kill someone, steal something, blow something up and/or fight someone, drive to point B and do it all again, sometimes while trying to avoid the police. Every mission was like this and there is no story surrounding the missions so things get very dull very fast. Also you have a lot less health in this than you did in the base game, and since there is no checkpoint system, you end up having to replay missions all over again including the tedious driving which tells you off whenever you try to speed which can frustrate you alongside bore you. I only played about 20% of this DLC content before getting bored and frustrated and turning it off. DO NOT BUY THIS DLC, it is not worth it. Also, the ending mission is the same thing again and the ending itself is about 30 seconds long. Yeah, don't bother.  What about Joe's Adventure's? Well, if you are reading this now, I am still playing through this DLC pack, however this review will be updated once I have completed it.

My main issues now after finishing the first run through of the story: NO FREEROAM!!! Unbelievable how this can have been left out. I mean the city is not particularly immersive in the first place but there is NO option to explore outside the storyline. This is unforgiveable. TOO EASY, even on the hardest setting there is little challenge. Only a few hours of play. STORYLINE, just not well thought out. Its not believable. The character makes odd choices that just leave me scratching my head going 'what an idiot' Its too hard to have any empathy for him. VEHICLES. Not enough, and far too many that dont even fit in the time period! Its made clear to you at the start of the mission what day and year it is, then you walk outside and get into a car that doesn't exist for another half of a decade.  THE MAP. Its pretty limited. Its not big, and the landmarks kind of annoy me. If its supposed to be set in New York, then fine, make the map resemble it at least vaguely and dont stick things in it from other cities like L.A. If its not supposed to be New York, Then don't stick the Brooklyn Bridge and the Empire State building in the middle of it. It just seems to give the city a tiny bit of identity (which is pointless) when the rest doesnt live up to it. A generic North Eastern city would have been easier to accept, without the landmarks.  Theres a lot of small details that annoy me too. Controllers?. Didn't detect my G27, could't get it working. In this day and age this shouldn't even be an issue. You can't drop an empty weapon, for example during firefights you can find your self with a shotgun, 2 tommy guns, an MP40, a grease gun, a 45, a magnum, and a .38, half of them are out of ammo and you have to cycle back and forth through the menu vainly searching for something to shoot back with. Also unfortunately there is no first person driving view. Multiple camera angles but none from inside the cabin.   Mafia 2 might be worth a punt if you find it on sale, but £30 for the digital deluxe verion is daft. The little DLCs are a bit annoying too as they clutter up your garage with unwanted vehicles you cant get rid of.  Honestly, I wouldn't bother with this. Its disappointing. I don't think I will get much use out of this now I have completed the story. I wouldn't say its a waste of money. But if I could get my money back, I would.

It serves simply as a means to get from location to location without sharp transitions. Do not go in expecting a GTA style open world. The story and characters are really the only thing that makes this game worth playing. Joe and Vito are characters I wanted to spend more time with, although if you've seen any mafia-style movie, you'll know exactly where the story is going. It's also got an unsatisfying ending that seemed placed just to set up a sequel. Ultimately I cannot recommend you buy Mafia II, but if you get it in a bundle or get it for free you should at least try it, you might like it.

You can run out of gas, get pulled over for speeding, take health damage (and possibly die) if you get in a bad enough accident.. all things that make sense and bring another level of realism to virtual driving. Stop your car, wait for the police to get out of theirs, then take off. That's all it takes to ditch the cops. And there goes all the tension of running out of gas during a high speed chase. There are three separate collectible achieves in this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. THREE. Collect all 50 Playboys, drive 30 of 36 cars, and find 150 wanted posters. That's nearly 250 different things to find. Whack. Totally and utterly whack. And this whackness doesn't even factor in the DLC achieve which involves driving 1k miles- an estimated 10 hours of time.  Boring game, punctuated by horrible achieves. Save your money. Buy something else.

Mafia 2 is a story driven adventure game set in the 50's in an open world and has third person shooting mechanics with a rudimentary cover system. Gameplay  The gameplay is one of the most monotonous games I have ever played. All you do is drive around aimlessly to your next mission which involves a bunch of thugs and rinse and repeat. There are no missions that have you do something different. The city is large but there are no side missions at all and the main story is broken into 15 chapters. There is a brawling mechanic which is the most basic I have seen you have 1 button to defend and then you attack. The game mechanics are just so pedestrian.There are no bugs in the gameplay in driving and shooting but there is an utter lack of variety. there are places to change clothes,change vehicles if you are wanted and the police in this game are just placed so that they could sometimes chase you around. Mafia II is a game for those who love a good mob story. I would like to see more family drama but Vito's journey is a trip worth taking. Throughout the game, you follow Vito as he climb up the ranks of the mafia, from petty theft to mass murder. Behind the glamour of crime, money and prostitution is a broken man who's unsure of himself. You slowly start to sympathize with Vito, as he gets torn between his family and his job and the consequences of his actions becomes dire. His best friend, Joe, is also involved in organized crime but his likability comes from his carefree spirit and loyalty. The overarching narrative is divided into chapters, allowing the story to flow together nicely.  If you're looking for a good game, you're much better off playing GTA, or L.A. Noire if you're into the 40-50s era. Much of the main missions are pretty mundane and repetitive. You spend most of the game driving from Point A to Point B, to Point C and back to Point A again. Shooting sections are fun but ordinary. Mafia II has a nicely detailed period setting but some of the textures are rather lackluster and the open world is pretty empty. You can barely interact or do anything despite the size of Empire Bay. The gameplay is rather linear, which isn't a problem if the main missions had more variety and there are no side-quests to speak off. The playboy collectibles are a nice touch for any horny youngsters out there.  Mafia II may be a story-driven game but that shouldn't come at the expense of gameplay. There are loads of games that are both story and gameplay-driven, though I can't think of many that are set in the 40s, so if that's your preference, Mafia II isn't a complete waste of money. If you're hoping for a mafia version of GTA, you'll be disappointed.  6/10 - ABOVE AVERAGE
